awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Descending neural control of a motor sequence in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
An animal's nervous system controls its behavior.  Complex behavioral sequences are assembled from simpler motor programs.  Like nest-building in birds and web-spinning in spiders, grooming in flies represents a flexible, innate, adaptive motor sequence.  This project will use the genetic tools available in flies, combined with new machine vision analysis, to identify the neurons that control fly grooming behavior.  It will focus on the connections between the brain and the ventral nervous system, since these descending neurons are a natural information bottleneck.  Understanding how a limited number of neurons convey commands and coordinate competing reflexes into productive behaviors will advance basic knowledge in neuroscience and provide conceptual insights into how any brain – including human ones – solve similar challenges.  One focus of the NSF's mission to promote basic science research is to understand the rules of life, and specifically to predict phenotypes.  This research contributes to ongoing efforts to generate maps of all the neurons and their connections in the fly by adding information about their behavioral functions. As part of the educational objectives of this project, the PI will organize a summer course at the Kavli Institute for Theoretical Physics for experimentalists and theorists that will involve both cutting edge topics in modern systems neuroscience and theoretical approaches. Specific efforts will be made to recruit undergraduate students to this quantitative biology summer course. 

This research will employ automated behavioral analysis of Drosophila grooming, optogenetic manipulations, and anatomical characterization of neuronal circuits.  Screens using new genetic reagents to target specific descending neurons will delineate their behavioral roles.  The project will characterize the projections and connections of these neurons to determine how they interface with sensory and motor circuits.  Activating combinations of descending neurons that initiate competing behavioral programs will reveal whether decisions are made in the brain or the ventral nerve cord.  Neural circuits that can be mapped in the fly represent fundamental motifs that perform computations common to all brains.  Understanding their roles in grooming behavior uses the advantages of this model to learn how the brain achieves motor sequences. The broader impact activities include a summer laboratory course in systems neuroscience as part of the ongoing KITP summer program in quantitative biology as well as undergraduate and graduate student training.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding how the nervous system coordinates appropriate behaviors is a challenge relevant to human health that we can investigate with basic science research in model organisms.  Neurons connecting the brain to the ventral nerve cord in the adult fly Drosophila represent a control bottleneck.  Sensory information and internal drives coordinated in the brain activate specific combinations of descending neurons to convey decisions about appropriate behavioral responses to the pre-motor circuits in the ventral cord that execute movements.  New genetic tools allow descending neurons to be activated or silenced to assess their behavioral effects, and new anatomical datasets allow their synaptic, network connections with other neurons to be mapped.

In this project, we identified descending neurons that can initiate different cleaning movements like those that normally remove dirt and debris from the fly’s body and we investigated how different combinations of neurons control assembly of individual cleaning movements into the sequential, coordinated grooming.  We showed that antennal cleaning, head cleaning, and front leg rubbing can be initiated separately or as alternating subroutines by different command-like descending neurons, allowing for both rhythmic and more flexibly targeted grooming.  Activating multiple descending neurons does not make the flies do two behaviors at once, showing that circuits for action selection are located downstream.  This demonstrates that modular and redundant control mechanisms may underlie motor sequence assembly. 

We characterized the GABAergic, inhibitory neurons that receive indirect synaptic input from descending neurons and coordinate pre-motor circuits within and between the legs.  Comprehensive anatomical and behavioral investigation of these neural types shows that they complement excitatory neurons to provide an alternative way to group which muscles co-contract, creating the muscle synergies and motor primitives that are the repeated building blocks of coordinated limb movements.  Some inhibitory neurons connect to many pre-motor neurons while others connect to only a few, suggesting a way that core leg movements can be tuned for grooming or walking.

Some types of neurons have “serial homologs”: anatomically similar neurons in each segment to the ventral nerve cord.  We identified a set of six ascending neurons, two per segment, whose activation evokes leg rubbing in behavioral screens.  These neurons have projections ascending from the ventral nerve cord to the brain, and there is a pair of descending neurons with similar connectivity that we discovered in the connectome data.  Differences in the commissural projections of the circuits connected to these neurons in the middle segment may explain why flies groom those body parts with a distinct combination of legs.

These experimental results illuminate the organizational logic that allows a small population of neurons to control a complex, flexible, and sequential repertoire of movements, providing a template to which the neural control of motor sequences in vertebrates can be compared.  

The research supported by this award informed teaching and outreach efforts, notably influencing the choice of topics for two summer programs hosted by the UCSB KITP, the neurophysics of locomotion (2022) and the coming neurophysics of active sensing (2025).  These programs and the associated quantitative biology schools bring experimentalists and theorists together for a month-long opportunity for collaboration and cross-training, exposing students and senior investigators to different ways of approaching questions in neuroscience.
